ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Learned a lot about the current geopolitical landscape in Asia, with an emphasis on China.
Learned a lot about the complex issues happening in South-East Asia primarily and how major world powers such as China and the United States are involved and invested.
I learned a great deal about China and Southeast Asian relations. It gave so much information about the dynamics between these countries and modern issues involved in international relations.

Overview of current ASEAN policies, Belt & Road Initiative, human trafficking issues at sea, and some cybersecurity, with guest lectures on China in the Arctic and China's space race. I wouldn't say the seminar covered any of the topics particularly in depth. I also learned how to craft a long argumentative/policy paper on a very specific issue for the final.

I only developed knowledge through the haphazard readings. I struggle to even call this class a course given its ridiculous "teaching style" and I'm embarrassed a comp lit professor is teaching a GLBL class. Tremendous waste of time and energy.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I really enjoyed the research portion of the class. I was able to delve deeply into the topic I was interested in with the help of Professor Tsu.

Professor Tsu was an absolute gem, as well as guest lecturer Professor Cohen. Both were incredibly insightful and definitely the greatest strengths of this course. However, not being able to hear enough of them was, in my opinion, the primary weakness of this class. Many meetings consisted of the class going around and asking questions, which was definitely valuable, but something that I felt overshadowed many aspects of this course. I just wish I could've heard Prof. Tsu and Prof. Cohen deliver some more lecture-style material (since I felt as if there was almost none). This is not to say that this class should be in lecture formatthe course definitely benefits from a small class size and a discussion-based stylesimply that I wish I could've experienced some more structured content, rather than primarily responses to various, semi-related student-posed questions.

I think this course is excellent! Professor Tsu and David Cohen clearly are experts at the forefront of the field and they have so much to teach all of the students. Together, they give an incredible course and invite guest lecturers who are similarly brilliant. Sometimes, I think it would have helped if the homework expectations / assigned readings were a bit more clear or made available via PDF to the class.

The course is a bit sporadic and its really difficult to know how you're doing/what is expected of you. However, this does allow for some interesting pivots in conversation that I felt I benefitted from.

The topics and readings were interesting, and it was great to listen to both Prof Tsu's and Prof Cohen's (guest professor) expert knowledge in their respective areas. However, the seminar didn't really focus on the readings we had, and was rather Q&A-based with either professor depending on the week, which could stifle discussion and conversation among peers. I found the abstract feedback session very helpful, so I do wish there were more workshops and general guidance on writing the final research paper, given that our whole grade is basically dependent on that. I would have also liked to see more of an emphasis on how all the topics we learned about connect with each other.

I felt the course was too detached and was simply a collection of reading assignments. The course did not have many conversations or discussions about the relevant topics. Students were assigned readings, then classes themselves were fragmented sessions in which the teacher addressed reading questions from individual students, often with no coherent overarching message.

Strengths: David Cohen, visiting professor from Stanford, actually ~taught~ the class. I have no earthly idea what Jing was doing or thinking. When he'd lecture, I'd actually pay attention (although after an entire year on Zoom it was quite surprising they still had no idea how to use Zoom? Sharing your screen is not that difficult what the hell) and write everything down that he said. He actually DID answer the questions we posed, whereas Jing never... actually.. answered them? Like um, why did we even ask if you were just gonna be like "great question" and not answer?  I ended up answering some of my peers' questions myself along with another classmate b/c the profs just would blatantly disregard the qs and go on tangents. WEAK: LITERALLY EVERYTHING. How is this even a course. How is she a tenured and named professor, not to mention the chair of CEAS? Teaching is a skill that Jing does not have. Class started late, class ended legit hours early, readings were assigned two days before they were due (including two books equaling 950+ pages together that no one actually read), and the only assignment is a 20-25 page research paper WITH NO GUIDANCE AT ALL. Just "write" and "save all of your sources in a zip file" and then you don't even get any feedback from there. No way to gauge how you're doing in class either.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I think the inclusion of David Cohen and guest lecturers were a really great way of making the best of the COVID virtual classes. In the event that classes are ever virtual again, I think it might be helpful to take a quick break in the middle of the seminars because they are a bit long.
Virtual engagement could have been improved with more discussion among peers, rather than just having students ask 1-2 questions per class.
Class was absolute garbage. Trash teaching, trash organization, trash assignments. Literally nothing allowed for virtual engagement.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Definitely. Not only did Professor Tsu co-teach the course with Professor David Cohen which was great to hear from both of them, but also the research portion of the class is really great.
Yes! Jing Tsu is a great professor and its a fun class to be in weekly.

Yes, it's overall a good survey/exploration of East/Southeast Asia, but can be disjointed. I found the final research project to be very engaging, because you get to really hone in on a specific topic of your choosing.

Absolutely not. Worst organized class at Yale. Actual garbage. Aptly described as "going to other people's office hours" because that's all it is. I'm too tired to elaborate, but why on earth would you pay for this? So bad. I'm so disappointed.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: NA
N/A
